name: RedgateSqlCiBuild
description: Build, test, sync and publish a DB with SQL CI
author: Redgate Software

inputs.name: operation
inputs.label: Operation
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the SQL CI operation you want to perform. Build, test, publish or sync.

inputs.name: dbFolder
inputs.label: Database Folder

options.RootFolder: Database scripts folder is in VCS root
options.SubFolder: Database scripts folder is a sub-folder of the VCS root

inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the source-controlled database you want to build.

inputs.name: subFolderPath
inputs.label: Subfolder Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter a path relative to your build VCS root.

inputs.name: packageName
inputs.label: Output Package Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: An ID for the package you want to build.

inputs.name: tempServerTypeBuild
inputs.label: Temporary Server Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: During the build step, SQL CI makes a copy of your database on a temporary server. By default, it uses LocalDB for this. If your database uses features that are not supported by LocalDB, such as Full-Text Search, you can use a temporary SQL Server database.

inputs.name: tempDatabaseNameBuild
inputs.label: Database
inputs.helpMarkDown: Leave this blank, and SQL CI will create a temporary database. You should only specify a database name here if you wish to use an existing database.

inputs.name: passwordBuild
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Password should reference a secret variable defined on the Variables tab.

inputs.name: packageId
inputs.label: Package ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: The ID of the package you want to test.

inputs.name: tempDatabaseName
inputs.label: Database
inputs.helpMarkDown: If you leave this blank, SQL CI will create a new database with a unique name, and delete it after the tests have run. If you want to use an Azure SQL Database as a test database, you must create a database and give the name here. SQL CI cannot create a temporary database in Azure SQL Database.

inputs.name: password
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Password should reference a secret variable defined on the Variables tab.

inputs.name: useSqlDataGenerator
inputs.label: Use Redgate Sql Data Generator
inputs.helpMarkDown: SQL Data Generator is not available for hosted build-agents.

inputs.name: autoSqlDataGenerator
inputs.label: Automatically generate data
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is checked, SQL Data Generator will automatically generate 1000 rows of test data per table. Data is generated intelligently based on a column's datatype, name and any keys.

inputs.name: sqlDataGeneratorFile
inputs.label: SQL Data Generator file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use test data created by SQL Data Generator. If you've already created a SQL Data Generator project file, include the file name. If you don't have an existing project file, don't specify a value and data will be genereated automatically.

inputs.name: runOnly
inputs.label: Run only specified class/test
inputs.helpMarkDown: To run a specific test class or test instead of every test, enter the test class and test name.

inputs.name: packageIdPublish
inputs.label: Package ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: The ID of the package.

inputs.name: nugetFeedUrl
inputs.label: NuGet feed URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: The fully-qualified URL for your NuGet feed.

inputs.name: nugetFeedApiKey
inputs.label: NuGet feed API key
inputs.helpMarkDown: If you're using a private NuGet feed, enter an API key for the NuGet feed.

inputs.name: packageIdSync
inputs.label: Package ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: The ID of the package you want to use to update the target database. It must be a package built by SQL CI.

inputs.name: passwordSync
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Password should reference a secret variable defined on the Variables tab.

inputs.name: additionalParams
inputs.label: Additional SQL Compare Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify SQL Compare switches to run on the command line. Leave this blank to use the default options.

inputs.name: nugetPackageVersion
inputs.label: NuGet Package Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The build number in the NuGet package name. This should be consistent across all build tasks. For example: 2.1.

inputs.name: nugetPackageVersionUseBuildNumber
inputs.label: Use build number
inputs.helpMarkDown: In most scenarios, and if you are using VSTS Release, you should use leave this unchecked. Then the package version will be always set to the version specified in the above option, regardless of build number. But if you are publishing to a NuGet stream, you will probably want to check this. Then, the package's version will be built from the version specified above and the current build number. This setting should be consistent across all build steps.
